trustfund: TF028065-CANADIAN CONSLT. COOP. PROGRAM,TF038083-GUINEA - POWER II,TF031252-AFRICA - CAPACITY BLDG. IN ENV. ECONOMY,TF021905-POWER II PROJECT,TF021906-POWER II PROJECT #2

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of this project is
            rated as unsatisfactory because, despite the satisfactory
            completion of most investment components and improvements in
            system capacity and availability, 1) it did not achieve the
            most important objective--to secure a viable private
            management contract for the power system; 2) it did not
            improve the power sector's productivity or financial
            condition; and 3) the performance of both IDA and the
            Borrower in implementing the project was deficient. Some key
            lessons learned are the following: Although the
            project's Staff Appraisal Report reflected most of the
            objectives in the Borrower's Letter of Sector
            Development Policy, IDA's wording of the objectives
            assigns higher priority to reform actions, while the LODP
            appears to emphasize more the physical extension of the
            system. Before proceeding with any restructuring or
            privatization operation, there must be internal government
            consensus on the objectives, detailed actions required, and
            scheduling of activities. A permanent private management
            contract for a utility may not be effective unless the
            private operator has full responsibility for the power
            system and does not have to depend on government actions to
            make the utility commercially viable. Supervision in the
            project's initial years was minimal despite the
            emphasis of the project's implementation plan on close
            supervision. Consequently there was a major loss in project
            momentum at the outset.
